sp.p: Now, Cupid! take the ſharpeſt arrow from your quiver, and convert it into a harpoon, to ſtrike this Leviathan in love for me!

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: I have ſhorten'd ſail, and left friend Bale's ſquadron, now in chace of his daughter, to come along-ſide of you, my little American packet.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Upon my word, Admiral, you pay me a very great compliment.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p:
Not I, ſweetheart; I hope I'm too much of a ſeaman to pay compliments.—But, in few words, I like you; and, what's more, though 'tis full fifty
years ſince I was rated a Midſhipman, you are the firſt I ever ſtruck my colovrs to.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I proteſt, Admiral, its dangerous to liſten to you: you naval gentlemen are ſo uſed to conqueſt, nothing can reſiſt you.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: I wiſh, fair Lady, I could make a conqueſt of your heart.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Make a prize of it, you ſhould ſay, Admiral.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: If ſuch a prize had fallen into my hands, all the jewels in the ſalt ſeas, ſhould not ranſom it from me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Admiral: there are many captures made, which do not turn out upon trial to be good prizes.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: That's very true, Ma'am; but when there is any foul play in the caſe, the veſſel is diſcharg'd at Doctors Commons.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: If I ſhould liſten to your profeſſions, how can I be certain that you are ſincere?

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: How do I know what degree of Latitude I am in, by taking an obſervation of the ſun when it is in the meridian?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Man is well expreſs'd by the ſun, before marriage; but I'm of opinion, the moon has more to do with him afterward: did you never take an obſervation of that planet?

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: I don' know how it is, Ma'am, but this converſation appears to me a kind of traverſe ſailing; and then a woman trims ſo ſharp, ſhe always gets the weather gage of me?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You promiſe then to be conſtant?

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: As the needle to the north.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: But marriage may prove an approach too cloſe, and when that happens, marriners report that there is always a great variation.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p:
Madam, your wit enables you to fire two broadſides to my one; then let me aim a ſhot ever ſo well, it does no manner of execution, for want of ſtrength in my powder: having obliged me therefore
to drop a-ſtern, I wiſh to know, before I ſheer off, whether I ſhall ever hoiſt my flag on board of the America.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Why, Admiral, my marriage depends entirely upon that of my couſin.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: Prithee, how?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I made a ſolemn promiſe never to give my hand to any man, till ſhe was diſpoſed of to Mr. Summers; and here I make another promiſe, never to marry at all, if ſhe's weded to the Colonel.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: That bears very hard upon me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: It does not ſingly, Sir—my reſolution is fix'd. Oh, that odious Colonel! it is he who has caus'd all our confuſion: I am told that he has declared, he will not leave the houſe without a wife.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: Say you ſo? I'll try him—I'll ſend him a challenge, and make him eat his words; or he ſhall blow old Cable out of the water.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Not for the world! ſo precious do I hold your life, that to preſerve it, I'd even break my promiſe and marry him myſelf?

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: And leave me to founder! I tell you what, Ma'am, I'll make him an offer of my ſiſter—He can't want a wife, more than ſhe wants a huſband? to my knowledge ſhe has been theſe twenty years heaving out the lead, but never cou'd get into proper ſoundings.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Do you think he'll have her?

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: If he wants a wife ſo much, he will.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well, do any thing but challenge him; try once more your influence with my uncle; 'twill break my heart if Charlotte's marriage with the Colonel ſhou'd oblige me to deny you.

div.p:
Old and ſeaſon'd as my own heart is, ſuch an accident wou'd go near ſtarting a plank in it. Well, Cable, you are come to your moorings at laſt—A wife has brought you too, and you'll have ſafe riding for the reſt of your life in the Downs—But hold, cries maſter Prudence, is it calm weather always in that quarter? Wives are a kind of ſmall craft, and when
they happen to carry but little ballaſt, a cap-full of wind overſets them.—Beſides, you are an old veſſel, Cable; fitter for a guard-ſhip than a convoy.—An old man of war may lie ſafe enough at the Nore, under doble anchors; and ſo may I at Bachelor's-Point with a ſingle hauſer; but ſhould either of us part from our ſtations, and the land ſqualls freſhen, why we may drive up in diſtreſs to Graveſend, and ground there.—Marriage is avoyage round the world; a man muſt expect to meet with all weathers before he completes it.—'Tis ſafe and pleaſant enough till we paſs the Cape of Good Hope; but it requires a ſhip without fault, and an able ſeaman, to double Cape Horn.

sp.speaker: Miſs Kitty.
sp.p: What, the refin'd, the reſerv'd, the ſentimental Miſs Bale, to elope after all!

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: You'd ſhape juſt the ſame courſe yourſelf, Kitty, if a young fellow to your mind propos'd the cruize.

sp.speaker: Miſs Kitty.
sp.p: I am always ſure of your good word, brother; but 'tis well known that Kitty Dreadnought is not one of the flirts of the preſent day.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: No; your day is paſt: but chear up, my girl, after all I think I have hit upon a meſs-mate for you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Kitty.
sp.p: Upon my word, you have a moſt delicate mode of communicating your ſentiments!—Fix'd upon a meſs-mate for me!

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: I mean a huſband; that is, if we can perſuade him to have you—now, in that caſe you muſt know, that having caſt my eyes on a fair damſel, I mean myſelf to grapple; ſo we ſhall both be in the Bilboes.

sp.speaker: Miſs Kitty.
sp.p: Why, brother, have you any notion of marriage?

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: Yes, I have; I hope you don't think me too old for the ſervice?

sp.speaker: Miſs Kitty.
sp.p: Oh! not at all; old batchelors take young wives every day, and charming lives they lead of it.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: None of your ſkits, Ma'am, or you ſhall lead ſomething elſe inſtead of a huſband.

sp.speaker: Miſs Kitty.
sp.p: But who is this charming ſwain you have choſen for your ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: What do you think of the Colonel who came down to marry Bale's daughter?

sp.speaker: Miſs Kitty.
sp.p: Lord, brother! what do you mean by propoſing a man to me for a huſband I never ſpoke to?

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: Spoke to!—Don't mind that; you'll make up your lee-way after marriage.—So, do you hear, Kitty; keep within my wake, and have a ſharp look-out—as ſoon as I make the ſignal, you may expect him to bear down immediately for the engagement.

div.p: This unexpected propoſal has put me all in a flutter—I ſhan't be able to look one of the family in the face, and they will ſo ſtare at me when the match comes to be talk'd of publicly!—I proteſt unmarried young women go through a great deal—the world takes a malicious pleaſure in putting them out of countenance.—But the trial ſcene will be, when he propoſes the thing to me himſelf!—My ſpirits will never ſupport me!

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: So you have never been married, Mr. Boreas?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Why, do you ſee, my pretty wench, I never met one to my mind before, tho' I have made as many voyages, and touched at as many ports, where ſalt water flows, as moſt navigators.

lg.l: If you'll conſent, my lovely dear,
To be a ſailor's wife,
By truth you'll find him always ſteer,
Throughout the cruize of life.
No jealous winds with rage ſhall roll,
To veer his courſe from love;
True as the needle to the pole,
His heart ſhall ever prove.
I've been on India's wealthy coaſt,
But nothing there I prize,
Like rubies which thoſe lips can boaſt,
Like diamonds in thoſe eyes.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: But, Mr. Boreas, won't the world ſay that you are rather too old for me?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Not at all—In chooſing a huſband, you ſhould act like an experienced carpenter, who always prefers ſeaſon'd oak to green timber.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Why, that's very true; and now I look at you again, I think your appearance wonderfully mended—better begin late than never.—I have often heard our gardener ſay, that if you nip a roſebud in the ſpring, it will bloſſom at Chriſtmas.—So now, as we are to be ſweethearts—and all that—I expect you'll do me a favour—

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Ay, that I will—

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Oh, Lord! that is n't the favour I wanted.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: But I know it is—ſo come, don't be ſhame-faced.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: No, no, Mr. Boreas!—The favour I wanted was, to try if you cou'dn't contrive to keep the Admiral here all night.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: I'm under ſailing orders already.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: But cou'dn't you appear as if you were a little overtaken in liquor?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.p: Why, look'ee, ſweetheart!—I hate falſe appearances of every kind—but if you'll contrive to get me the ſtuff, in leſs than an hour I'll contrive to be upon my beam-ends.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.p: Then come along, and you ſhall have a bottle of Madeira to begin with.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Truth is the cordage binds my heart,
And that will break if we muſt part.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: The pr'ythee be advis'd by me,
And Love your pilot ſafe ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: By the ſtars above I've known
Rocks and ſhelves at night to ſhun;
But thoſe eyes henceforth ſhall be
Like the ſtars in heav'n to me.

sp.speaker: Rach.
sp.l: Oh, what a charming ſwain is mine!

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Oh, what a blooming prize is mine!

div.stage: SCENE changes to a dark Room.—Enter MOUNTFORD and CHARLOTTE, muffled up in a long Cloak.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: This, Madam, is the houſe—you'll excuſe me leaving you in the dark; you ſhall have lights immediately.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: This gentleman, though a ſtranger to me, is Summers's friend, and as ſuch I have relied on him. —Perhaps it was imprudent to accept of his protection without knowing him better; but my fears deprived me of all reflection.—I have one comfort, however, to think it is better being taken any where than home again.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: For fear of diſcoveries, you ſee, Ma'am, I have brought the lights myſelf—and now I'll go for my dear Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p:
His dear Charlotte!—I find this lady and I are name-ſakes.— Looks round her with aſtoniſhment. —Can I credit my ſenſes?—Why, he has brought me to my own houſe!—What madneſs, to put myſelf in the power of an utter ſtranger! This man has been ſuborn'd by my father, and, under pretence of friendſhip for Summers, has betrayed me.—What ſhall I do?—Which way ſhall I turn me, to ſhun the
ruin hanging o'er my head!—There is no way of avoiding it; I reſign myſelf to my fate.
sp.stage: Throws herſelf in a chair, and appears buried in deſpondency.

div.stage: ANGELICA and MOUNTFORD appear behind CHARLOTTE, at the upper end of the Stage.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Who in the world can he have got with him?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: She is belov'd by that friend I eſteem moſt upon earth; and as ſuch I beg you wou'd conſider her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Your recommendation, Colonel, would go a great way towards winning my eſteem for any body; but one of my own ſex, and unhappy, has a claim upon my heart for every ſervice it can render her.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Generous girl! I expected you would ſay as much.—But come, let me make you and this lady acquainted.—Madam, give me leave [Mount. and Ang. advance towards Char.] to introduce you.

div.stage: [Char. looks up at him and Ang.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Oh, Heavens! is it you?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: What then, you know each other?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: It ſeems, Sir, as if that ſurprized you!

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: It does, upon my ſoul! but I am very glad of it—for now, I ſuppoſe, I may leave you together without ceremony.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Whenever you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: I am going to ſpeak to Mr. Bale.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Does he know nothing of my being here yet?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Not a ſyllable; but ſuppoſe I let him into the ſecret?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: The ſooner the better; when that's over, my mind will be ſomewhat eaſier.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: You are perfectly right, Ma'am; and therefore I'll go find him immediately.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Before you go, I inſiſt upon ſpeaking to you.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Yonder I ſee him walking along the gallery—don't let me loſe this opportunity—I muſt hit him to a ſecond, or there is no ſpeaking to him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Stay, Colonel—Mountford, come back!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Can that poſſibly be Colonel Mountford?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: He himſelf—by whatever wonderful turn of chance you came into his power.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: I ſcarcely know myſelf—all I can tell you is, that I ſaw him in Summers' company; ſuppoſed him his friend, and put myſelf under his protection.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Then your being brought here, was a plot concerted between this man and your father?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Don't you perceive it?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Too plainly for my happineſs—and yet when I conſider the matter more maturely, I am half inclined to think he did not know you—you remember his ſervant already took me for you; and he himſelf, to the laſt moment, addreſſed me by the name of Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Grant that he might for ſome time have been under a miſtake of that nature; don't you imagine that my father has long ſince undeceiv'd him? no, it was a deep laid ſcheme, to impoſe on the credulity of poor Summers.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: If your ſuſpicions be well founded, he is the moſt accompliſhed of Hypocrites—when he recommended you juſt now to my protection, his words, his every look breathed nothing but ſincerity and compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: The villain who wears his purpoſe in his face will be ſhunned; he muſt ſheath his dagger in a ſmile before he can wound with it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Oh, that every heart was like mine, a ſtranger to diſſimulation! Why is the countenance made a maſk for the ſoul, when it ſhould be a mirror, in which every eye might behold the true features of the mind, in the deformity of vice, or the lovelineſs of virtue!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Now all's over, here he comes with my father!

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: I tell you Colonel, you are deceiv'd —it is not poſſible!

div.stage: Enter BALE and MOUNTFORD; the former appears aſtoniſhed, ſeeing CHARLOTTE.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Eh! my eyes are none of the beſt; but if there be any dependance on them, that is my daughter Charlotte.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: Now, Angelica, what do you think of the honour of your Colonel?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Let us leave the room; the ſhock of being diſappointed in my opinion of him, is more than my ſpirits can bear.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Did you take notice of the other young lady in company with Miſs Bale?

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Certainly I did.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Have you any objection to her continuing in the family a few days?

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Objection! Zounds! what objection can I poſſibly have?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Why to-be ſure, Sir, you can have no reaſonable objection; and yet it's not one man in a thouſand who wou'd be ſo indulgent.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Indulgent do you call it? Damme! if I'd bid her quit my houſe, if ſhe choſe to remain in it theſe twenty years.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, this is very kind, very kind of you indeed; and be aſſured I ſhall ever gratefully remember the obligation?

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Upon my word this is very pleaſant. But ſeriouſly, Colonel, do you think it ſuch a favour, that I permit my niece to continue in the houſe with her couſin?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: What then, ſhe's your niece?

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Only my brother's daughter.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Oh, the devil! I have made a charming blunder, to bring a woman who had eloped, to the houſe of her uncle—I might as well have brought her to her father's.

sp.speaker: Carb.
sp.p: A word in your ear, Sir.

div.stage: [Carb. and Mount, retire to the back of the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: I am ſo perplex'd with falſe appearances on every ſide, that I cannot diſtinguiſh between the ſhadow and the ſubſtance. Well, if Charlotte did elope, it is evident the Colonel knows nothing of the matter; and it's not my buſineſs to undeceive him— there is ſomething very extraordinary in all this! and yet there may be method in it, if I cou'd find it out.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Go warn him inſtantly of his danger.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Summers is in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Summers! what a piece of aſſurance!

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Don't be angry with him, Sir; for he never wou'd have come here, if I had n't ſuggeſted the ſcheme.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: O, then this was a ſcheme of your ſuggeſting?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Entirely—and as he has taken up his quarters with you, I hope you won't drive him out of the garriſon.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: There are certain quarters in Moorfields that I think will become your garriſon.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Come, come, Mr. Bale, you muſt be poor Summers's friend—nay, I inſiſt upon it.—If you knew how many good qualities he poſſeſſed, by Heaven! you wou'd regard him as a ſon.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Zounds! wou'd you wiſh that he was my ſon?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: I wiſh he was your nephew.

sp.speaker: Summers.
sp.p: I inſiſt upon admittance.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Mr. Bale, you may think it extraordinary to ſee me in your houſe—but do not attribute my preſence to either diſreſpect, or any intention of injury; before I came here I was trepann'd by a falſe friend.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Damme! if I don't think you both were trepan'd.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Was it at me, Summers, you levell'd that inſinuation?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: At you, Mountford—once the friend of my boſom, who has ſtung my heart, becauſe he was neareſt to it.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Was ever any thing ſo unreaſonable as this man? I was juſt making your peace with Mr. Bale.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Perfidious Hypocrite! do not attempt any longer to impoſe on my credulity—why did n't you avow the truth like a man, when you knew my paſſion for Charlotte?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: For whom?

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: For my daughter—whom this good friend of your's was endeavouring to ſteal away from you.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: He pretended love to your niece.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: That was all a pretence to impoſe upon you.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Dare you maintain to my face, Summers, that it is to the daughter of this gentleman your pretenſions aſpire?

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Dare I?—I never will reſign my claim to her, but with my life!

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Then you ſhall win her at the hazard of that life.—Draw, thou diſhonour to the name of friend!

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: Ay, this is acting the villain with conſiſtency!

sp.speaker: Adm.
sp.p: What, friends and allies exchanging broadſides! —Break up the line, I ſay, immediately!

div.stage: Strikes up their points with his ſword.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, Colonel—though we are interrupted now, depend upon it, you ſhall not carry off the prize ſo eaſily.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, Sir; but I wiſh you would carry yourſelf out of my houſe.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: No, Mr. Bale—let him ſtay till I convince him that his paſſion for my dear Charlotte is ridiculouſly ill-founded; as a proof of it, Summers, here I ſolemnly engage to reſign all claim to her, if ſhe gives you the preference.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: No, no, Colonel—there is no ſuch generoſity about you!

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: By Heaven! I am ſerious—and here comes the lady to ratify my ſincerity.

sp.speaker: Sum.
sp.p: My dear Charlotte!—

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.stage: [Interrupting him, and taking Angelica by the hand.]
sp.p: No, Sir, here is your dear Charlotte—and if ſhe declares—

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Before I hear any more declarations from you, Colonel, tell me who do you think that lady is?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Your daughter, Sir, to be ſure!—my ever adorable Charlotte!

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: She may be your ever adorable—but ſhe happens to be my niece Angelica!

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Is this true, Ma'am?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: It is even ſo, Sir—but I hope it was not to a name that you have been making ſo many paſſionate profeſſions?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Madam, your beauty, your accompliſhments, have rivetted fetters upon my heart, no earthly power can break aſunder!

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Though matters are not taking the turn I could wiſh, there is ſomething like the appearance of method at laſt.—Well, Colonel, as there can be no more miſtakes, let me introduce you to the real Charlotte, who is to be your wife.

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: I beg leave to withdraw my claim, Sir, in favor of my friend Summers, who, I hope, is now convinc'd I never entertain'd a thought of taking his miſtreſs from him. Your beauteous niece—

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: What the devil, Sir! are you going to annul the bargain between your father and me?—Beſides, Sir, my beauteous niece is diſpos'd of.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What! without my own conſent?

sp.speaker: Mount.
sp.p: Diſpos'd of! to whom?

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: To my friend here, the Admiral—this • ine old ſeaman; that, if all our Commanders were like him, not a power in Europe dare fire a gun upon the ſeas without the conſent of England.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: Avaſt, avaſt! friend Bale!—Flattery is a quickſand, and let us ſteer clear of it.—The lady is about to be put in commiſſion with a better officer. —When you propos'd the match to me, I knew nothing of there being younger claims in queſtion; if I had, be aſſured I ſhould not be ſo much out of my latitude.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: So, I am left in the lurch by all parties!

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: What, when a fine young fellow, with a good fortune, is looking out for the fair wind of your conſent to marry your daughter?—Friend Bale, for a long time I have had a great regard for you; but I am ſorry to remark, that, in this caſe, you have put to ſea more with a view to making a prize, than doing the duty which honor requires of you.—Some fathers treat their children as if they were trafficking in gold duſt and elephants teeth, and had forgot that the ſlave trade was aboliſhed in England.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Between ourſelves, Admiral, as my daughter went off with him, and this Colonel won't have her, I ſhould have no objection to giving my conſent, only I am afraid I ſhall loſe my character for ever by it, as a man of method.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: But you'll gain a point in the other courſe, and eſtabliſh your character as a man of underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p:
Well, Summers, as Charlotte appears determin'd to have nobody but you, I'll let the Colonel ſee he ſhan't overturn all my calculations.—You ſhall have my daughter; but you muſt get into Parliament as faſt as you can.—I expected to ſee a branch
of my family in the Houſe of Peers; but I am determin'd not to be ſhut out of both Houſes.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: You are come too late, Kitt; there's not a ſweetheart left for you, unleſs my friend Bale will have you.

sp.speaker: Miſs Kitty.
sp.p: You take a pleaſure, brother, in putting me out of countenance.—Truly, if every body thought as little of the ſubject as I do!—

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Come, come, Miſs Kitty, don't be offended with the Admiral; now Charlotte's off my hands, I conſider myſelf a ſpruce batchelor again, and if the fair Miſs Dreadnought—

sp.speaker: Miſs Kitty,
sp.p: Mr. Bale, let me beg of you!—I aſſure you, Sir, this is converſation I have not been uſed to.

sp.speaker: Dread.
sp.p: Not theſe fifteen years, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Bale.
sp.p: Colonel, give me your hand—we are friends once more. Take notice, Summers, that I have ſet down in the future arrangements of my family, a Biſhop, and a General Officer. Good folks, I have a band of muſic, and an excellent ſupper provided—if it is not ſpoil'd by being over-done. [Looks at his watch.] Od'ſo • it is fifteen minutes paſt ten!—In conſequence of the viciſſitudes of this day, I ſhall ſup later by an hour and a quarter than I have theſe twenty years. Angelica, my girl, I'll be your father when you go to church—and as you are reſolved to ſettle on this ſide of the Weſtern Ocean, the firſt toaſt after ſupper ſhall be, The union of England and America!

lg.l: That's a union ev'ry heart
Pants to ſee compleat again!
May they meet and never part,
But like brothers ſtill remain.
Then wou'd Britain ſoon behold,
Peace return, a pilgrim bleſt!
And the Parent State enfold
All her children to her breaſt!
